Sorry Derek, I am always Team Veritasium, but your implied statement around why America abandoned precision bombing during WW2 is grossly disingenious. America abandoned precision bombing in WW2 because they discovered the jetstream and what they had at the time could not compensate for the increased speeds planes were moving at during their bombing runs. Yes, part of this relied on the Norden Bombsight, but the sights more or less would have been fine had it not been for said jetstream.

I am a meteorology student and my university is very old fashioned. I had to do a lab course for meteorological instruments, and one of them involved using an analog computer to measure the humidity. The device contained human hairs and the computer was able to measure how much the hairs stretch and draw a graph of the humidity. The tutor asked me beforehand what I expected to see, and I said an exponential curve, and the thing really did draw a perfect exponential curve. I remember both my partner and I were kind of fascinated by it even though nobody would ever actually use such an archaic device anymore.

The wild thing about this isn't that its an analog computer nor that it deduces based on observation, but that this technology existed at point in time but was lost in transit (potentially). But that creates an question that had it not been lost in transit (potentially), had it made its way to its destination and had it become mainstream--what kind of material impact would it have had on how mathematics, science, (what would become physics), and countless other disciplines that make up our world and economy? It's a mechanism that greatly reduced calculation time. Banks as we know today are massive computational networks. Most machinery is based on math, material science, physics, exact tolerances, and are all juggling games of maximizing efficiency per unit of energy used relative to the amount of work done to produce a useful good, where the goal is to be net+1 or net+10.

All of this is of course a what if now, because the device never made it, supposedly, to where its supposed to go. But its an interesting thought experiment to consider what else could something like this have helped amplify in other areas of the world.

Early 70's when we started working Fire Control, Digital fire control had only just started, so we had to learn both. While some ships had digital; most then were still analogue. The first digital gunnery FC computer we had had 2K of memory and ran it's entire program in 1/2 a second. Sounds ludicrous now. It is preserved in the Daring class Destroyer HMAS Vampire in Sydney (museum).

By the late 80's, the analogue systems were all gone (apart from small, secondary functions) as digital took over.

But the analogue systems were a work of art from a precision mechanical standpoint was concerned. Multiple mechanical computation devices such as differentials and integrators (as above, also known in our (Navy) circles as "potters wheels") that were made with a level of precision seldom seen in other devices.

I worked on that stuff for 40 years, and while the hardware changed, the calculations done didn't.

Was an interesting job, I enjoyed every minute of it.

17:14 fun fact, you only need either AND or OR, not both.
since one gate can be created using the other and NOT.
and AND gate can be made by inverting all inputs and the output of an OR gate, and an OR gate can be made in the same way using an AND gate.

Excellent presentation. When I was doing my aerospace masters in 1981, I had a project to simulate an unstable combat aircraft and then to add the effect of an active control system to stabilise and control it. This was all analogue using potentiometers and amplifiers. The reason was that analogue computers have the immediate response needed to bring a dynamically unstable systems under control without introducing nuisance and limit cycle oscillations. All artificial stability systems for aircraft at the time had an active end built as an analogue computer, even if the pilot input end was still digital. It was a very powerful lesson. As my tutor observed, in general with digital systems you can have fast or you can have powerful. With analogue computing, it's possible to make the sensor the source of power (as in aerodynamic servo tabs, the BAe146 regional jet has an entirely analogue pitch control system involving a devious concoction of pneumatic, aerodynamic and inertial devices), the result can be both fast (=responsive) and powerful.

Building Heating, Ventilation and Air Conditioning was controlled by analog computers up until the early 1980s.
These were mainly pneumatic using 3-13 psi as a control signal range sensing temperature error signals and computing proportional and integral control functions.
Other analog control computers were electric or electronic.
The Australian HIFAR nuclear reactor secondary cooling system was controlled by electronic modules calculating square-root functions, proportional and integral functions without any software.

Uh, as a long time TV viewer, I would take issue at the statement “digital is more robust” in the presence of noise. I can tune in a non digital TV station that is far away... even though the signal is poor, I am able to see and listen. As anyone who has used a digital TV antenna can tell you, even a relatively close station with a signal that is getting interrupted is totally not viewable. DTV cannot be watched at all when the digital bits are dropped or missing, whereas analog can still be received and viewed albeit in poor quality.

Another application of analog computers (I presume) is in the aiming of battleship guns, which, when you think about it, must take into account a number of variables in real time. I saw on a YouTube video a while back that the shell from a large naval cannon can take as long as 90 seconds to reach its target. At the speed they travel, that is a long way. Over that distance, the target ship would appear tiny - if it is not over the horizon - and must require extraordinary accuracy, as moving the cannon through as little as 0.1 degrees would definitely put it off-target. This accuracy has to be maintained, taking into account the rolling and pitching of the ship, and the motion of the target, assuming it is also a ship. At full range, the cannon must not fire at where the other ship is, but at where it will be in 90 seconds. When you see a ship in port, everything is moving very slowly, but at sea, they move along quite quickly, with a displacement of several lengths during the time of travel of the shell. If a gun boat is to stand any chance of hitting a moving target from its unsteady platform, there must be some pretty fancy computation behind it - and during the last war, there was no digital control available.

As a computer scientist, I am well aware of analog computers, analog computing, and its advantages and disadvantages. There are also hundreds (yes hundreds) of alternative computing methods and devices that were relegated to obscurity by the simple fact that digital computing is cheaper and more efficient for a wide range of applications. The slide rule (for example) represents logarithmic computing, yet we don't call them computers because they are usually implemented as manual devices. Likewise, Dick Hamming ran through a number of alternative computing approaches when I took his course in Grad School. One of the best features of digital computing, however, is that it has brought computing to the masses. You don't have to be a computer scientist to take advantage of digital computers. In fact, although interesting, the substance of this video is of little value to most professions.

There are analog computers that are highly programmable / changeable. They use "patch panels", one for each application. The panels are thick aluminum boards that contain holes for wire cables between components. When engaged, the panel / wires connect to op amps and other circuit components inside the computer. The wiring of the panel determines what functions and calculations are performed. These installations also typically link the analog system to a digital computer, for auxiliary computing and I/O. I used one of these analog computers, the EAI 680, at Purdue University EE Department in the 1970's.

I tried inserting a link to the photos and description website, but then this channel instantly deleted my comment. You can view the EAI 680 by searching for Analog Museum. Then go to the Collections section and view their page on the EAI 680. Many other fascinating pages at that site as well.

When I was a kid - around 1960 - I built (from a kit) a computer that was kind of like your white, grey and black three wheel computer, except it used audio tones for multiplication and division problems. When you would set the first wheel to a number, you would hear a tone of a specific pitch that related to the number. Then you would turn the second wheel to another number and you would hear a second tone, the pitch of which was different if you set it to a different number than the first wheel. Then you would turn the third wheel until the two pitches merged into one pitch, and the number that the third wheel pointed to was the answer.

One minor problem with those calculations they do not include: When the sun, moon, and Earth are in alignment (at the time of the new or full moon), the solar tide has an additive effect on the lunar tide, creating extra-high high tides, and very low, low tides—both commonly called spring tides. One week later, when the sun and moon are at right angles to each other, the solar tide partially cancels out the lunar tide and produces moderate tides known as neap tides. During each lunar month, two sets of spring tides and two sets of neap tides occur (Sumich, J.L., 1996).  From NOAA

Was at the wavefront of the analog-to-digital resolution in engineering. During an experimental study with large lasers in 1986, we took data with high speed 16mm film, but was able to digitize the outline of hand drawings made from the film on an artist's bench. From the digitized data, we could compute laser irradiance. 16mm is gone and digital cameras are must faster. Programs change the images to outlines, and combining the time stamp from each digital frame, we can get the same data in about....10 milliseconds. A little faster than the three hours we used to need.

Analogue machines in the old style were objects of great beauty, and in many cases the result of superb craftsmanship. They were however very expensive, and had to be lovingly maintained, since they were prone to malfunction due to the build of of dirt. Inevitably too they gave inaccurate results. A secondary effect was cumulative error as a result of rounding errors in a lengthy calculation.

On a personal level I used a slide rule for many years in my early career as a design engineer, but was blown away by my first electronic calculator - a Texas Instruments machine which by modern standards would be considered pathetic. That was in the 1970's.

I shall look forward to viewing a further piece on a possible comeback for analogue computers, but am sceptical that they can ever overcome the problems inherent in this king of machine.

It had a 3/8" hole at the top and bottom. Some water had gotten inside and was rusty. In washing out the rust in my kitchen sink, the globe fell into and sealed the garbage disposal entrance. I wondered what would happen when as the water level rose in the sink. I supposed the globe would float at some point, allowing the water to drain out, and the lowering level would drop the globe back into the hole, reselling it. Thus it would be a crude regulator of level as the globe alternately floated and sank. But this did not happen! The globe remained in place until the water rose over the top of the globe whereupon some water began draining through the globe via the two 3/8" holes. Yet the level continued to rise as there was more water from the faucet entering the sink than there was draining through the globe. After a half of inch more water entered, the globe suddenly popped up like a submarine surfacing. Then the sink drained around the globe. I repeated this, starting from an empty sink and saw the same result. What causes this, and what are the factors involved? I did not investigate (yet) what would happen if the axis of the 3/8" holes was tilted vs. vertical.

tbh I dont think fully analog computing will ever catch on. There are as of now two ways to compute stuff in an analog way. Mechanical and Electrical. Mechanical has failed us already. We had incredibly intricate machines, but for them to reach the same efficiency as mordern digital ways is quite impossible/impractical.
So only electrical remains. This is just... very very hard. For analog stuff to be mass produced, you need really good tolerances on every important part of the process or manually tune every single device. In the end, its probably easier to automate the tuning as well. So that may not stop us. Then there is the actual designing part. Stuff in analog electrics is incredibly non-linear. You have to deal with semiconductors (I will just assume that) and those vary harshly on a lot of variables, some are just purely statistical. Even if you use like 300nm processes, basically the oldest ones you will find in modern cpus, you would probably need VERY high computational power to simulate and error-correct analog computers so that they will work. And you cant do that for like one design and be done with it, no, your load gets increased exponentially for each component, since they can have infinite values. Right now there are tolerances. Like, one place on the chip may only ever get like 1.0 V instead of 1.2 V but thats fine for that place, another one gets 1.20 V and if it gets much lower, the chip will probably struggle. With analog, there is no such redundancy. Everything needs to be calculated PRECISELY. For modern chips this simulation alone would probably take years. And that would need to be run a few times, for each time you correct errors.

So all in all, at least with modern chips you wont get analog computing running. What I can imagine instead is a new kind of math used, like instead of boolean algebra some other algebra with 4 values instead of 2, or 8. That could drastically increase computational power. Quantum computing does something like that, tho in a very... special way. And then with time those 2 or 4 values may increase even more. But (to my knowledge) such math that is as complete as boolean algebra doesnt quite exist yet and for that to work, there will probably a penalty in terms of power consumption and design complexity. Every single part of a cpu would have to be redesigned and that in a more efficient way. That will only happen once we truly reach the borders of computing with the binary system, and I recon some stuff like light computing or smth will replace silicon computing sooner or later.

As long as we use this equation [F?m?M/r^2] we need to pay heed to the small print it comes with. This small print tells us that matter is not the seat of gravity. Newton uses the center of a mass as mathematical artifact purely for calculation, but when you “go” to the center of any mass, you will find nothing there, gravity is zero at the center of any mass. It is therefore why mass has no “weight” onto itself. That can be shown mathematically, but let’s approach it logically - which everything in physics must be done if you want to understand: if you want to know what Mount Everest weighs, you cannot plug in [W=m?g] with the full [g] of earth, you have to subtract the mass of the mountain from the mass of the earth and then calculate a new [g] for earth with which to multiply the mountains mass. Now, go on and take an ever greater junk of earth and recalculate the “weight” of it in respect to an ever decreasing mass of the “rest earth” …… when you finally arrive at the center and ask what the weight of the entire earth is in respect to a zero left over mass at the center, the result is zero: the weight of the entire earth is zero …… the problem is that in everyday life we never talk about weight, we talk about mass. When we say we “weigh” 80kg we mean our mass, our weight is W=m?g=80kg?9,8m/s^2=784N

Mass is NOT a force, Weight IS: F=m?a?W=m?g. Because bodies do not have weight “in them”, but only in respect to other masses, no mass has a force in it which could produce pressure, and therefore the concept of a self-pressurized sun is physically speaking nonsense. So is the idea that there is super high pressure at the center of earth. This fallacy can be easily shown mathematically, because the equation used to describe the pressure at the center of masses is P=??g?h. This is the equation for hydrostatic equilibrium which works fine to calculate the pressure of a column of water or at certain depths of the ocean - because you have value for [g]. At the center of any mass though, g=0 and therefore P=0. The center of a mass is NOT the seat of [g] and therein lies the authority of Newton.


“….or they reach equilibrium with the environment.” What do you mean by that? what is the result of such equilibrium.” What I mean is, that in absence of an enclosure or any outside force a cloud of gas in space will expand until it reaches thermodynamic equilibrium with space (“The natural state of things is the vacuum of space” as you put it) and that is a temperature of around 3K and pressure of something like e-18Pa. The amount of gas assumed to make up the sun would expand to a volume of V=nRT/P=4.2e51m^3. For comparison, that would be over 10 orders of magnitude larger than the Volume of the solar system with a radius of 120AU … V=4/3pr^3=2e40m^3

“Gravity acts at molecular level, not in the formation of molecules.” please forget gravity when talking molecules, which are formed by chemical bonds. The forces of these bonds are 30 orders of magnitude stronger than any gravity, that means gravity is less than negligible on that level.

“Each molecule interacts with the other….” the only interaction between molecules in a gas is “bouncing off each other”, thus creating the pressure and temperature characterizing the state of a gas - only chemistry and electromagnetism is strong enough to influence and restrict that bouncing from within a gas, everything else has to come from outside, like the wall of an enclosure or gravity.

This is a very nice video with among other things a fine survey of Kelvins tide predictor. But I think there is an error in the animation of his ball and disc integrator. Most integrators of this type used a small wheel which had to slip on the disc when moved sideways. But Kelvin (or his brother) used a ball which could roll in all directions. Hence it could not have a fixed axle (as it have in the animation!) but must transfer the rotation to a cylinder which do have an axle (also shown in the animation but without the proper explanation).

Derek cited the book in the description but I am afraid it might be overlooked so I'm going to specifically recommend "The Bomber Mafia" by Malcolm Gladwell to anyone interested in learning more about the Norden bombsight and the American efforts to use precision bombing efforts against German and Japanese troops.

The failure of the device led to the firebombing campaign mentioned in the video which killed a staggering amount of people. Estimates suggest that more than 100,000 people might have been killed in a single night (in Tokyo) and roughly one million were left homeless. That's roughly the same number of deaths as both the Hiroshima and Nagasaki nuclear blasts (although many more would later die due to lasting effects of radiation).

The Norden bombsight was a brilliant device. Had it worked as intended outside of lab conditions, it's likely that the war would have been ended with far fewer civilian casualties because the Allies intended to target only a small number of strategic locations (like a ball bearing facility in southern Germany).

There is a very important reason, why analog computers will never truly take over digital ones: error correction. The problem is that when you calculate a function, you include some error in the result. And the biggest problem is the ambiguity created by this. This results in overlaps between the results of calculations. So it is possible that f(x, t1) = f(x + delta, t2) (the result at some time for input x is the same as the result at some other time for an other value, different by delta.)

Now to make things useful, the probability of overlapping needs to be reduced. But for this the inputs need to be quantized. The larger delta is, the less likely this overlap is. So essentially analog computers are digital computers with more than two levels.

The worm gear on the back of my camshaft is an analog computer.  It rotates the distributor shaft to time the spark ignition with the top of the power stroke.  Timing the engine is adjusting the distributor shaft so that the spark without vacuum advance hits when the timing mark is passing a certain mark, say 6 degrees below top dead center.  The timing chain connects the crankshaft to the camshaft so that the camshaft rotates once for every two times the crankshaft rotates.  Classic car engines are analog computers.  As are the transmission gear boxes and the differential gears.

So, fun fact, when USS Missouri was being reactivated and refitted prior to the Gulf War the US Navy approached IBM about the ballistic computers since they were the ones that made and installed them way back in the day. Keep in mind, this is the fire control system for the WHOLE ship, from the 20mm Oerlikons that form the base of the holy trinity of anti-air, all the way up the main 16" guns in turrets that weigh more than some smaller ships. This system weighed dozens of tons and was integrated at every level into the ship, armor would have to be removed to get at it, entire compartments were devoted to this thing, it would have been a PROCESS to replace it.

So the Navy asks IBM if they can upgrade it? For a nice juicey government check? ABSOLUTELY WE CAN! It'll be all new and digital and take up so much less space, save so much weight. The Navy says that those are both nice things, but can it be made more accurate? Well... No. No we cannot. The Navy did not upgrade Missouri's fire control system from analog to digital.

Actually, the ENIAC was neither the first programmable nor even the first one of it's kind at all. And though the AB-Computer was digital it wasn't fully programmable.
No, instead the first fully functional programmable digital computer was, ironically, the German Z3 in 1941. Ironic because the same kind of thing cracked the German Enigma in other countries. However they weren't made by request of the state yet, and even later it was just a sort of side project. AFAIK the small company/group that made them did receive financial support but that's it, the computers didn't see much use aside from assistance in developing some projects the group was also involved in by running simple programs. Also they were based, but on electromechanical relays (which functionally identical to transistors but use moving parts instead of a semiconductor) instead of vacuum tubes or transistors. Later on more models were sold, and these were actually some of the first commercial computers in Europe as well, though like 20 years later the company was bought and the story pretty much ends there.

These first computers may not have been that significant, but they shouldn't be ignored.

This task of adding sine waves reminded me of some amazing and not very well known work done by Prof Zharkova of the University of Northumbria in the UK with regard to predicting the effect of solar activity on global temperature (CO2 levels have very little to do with global temp in reality. I know, heresy!).  Anyway, the way Prof Zharkova did it was to collect several sine waves from the magnetic magneto-like activity of the Sun and she fed those sine waves into a program she acquired for free that produced the sum of those sine waves.  The Prof then back tested the resulting formula/algorithm using a dataset of solar activity going back to the ancient Chinese era to modern NASA satellite/probe data in order to prove the algorithm - it matched very closely.  On that foundation, the Prof then ran predictions for future global temperatures.  She's been ignored by Climate Inc. because her findings have been that Earth is entering a cooling period (ie. counter-narrative). People forget that in our world, everything can compute and is computing. Let a rock fall from your hand and count the distance and seconds and you are computing gravity. But more specifically in Electronics, circuits are always computers. They compute their results. You can "Hack" into that and build circuits that can model your specific computations. This is why we have "Operational Amplifiers" in electronics. They are used to do analog computations. A simple Resistor-Capacitor circuit is a computer too, it can be an imperfect differentiator or an integrator. Get an OpAmp now and you can have better differential equations. Anyhow, this video shows why this universe is so magnificent and why dedicating one's life to engineering and science is of high priority.

The digital and the analog computing systems are "representation of information". In the digital one, we omet some information in the Fourier serie transformation to get the "bit": one or zero which gives more precision, in the analog one, we get more information by scotching it as it is in the mechanical machine, but with more errors. To put it simple in an example: old photograph machines had incredible resolution, you can print them as large without losing much resolution but, the images contains imperfections, for numerical images they look good and perfect, as you zoom-in you see those pexels with lines, so the continuity is lost in the digital system. Another example is the old analog receivers for TV channels, where you can get the signal in a large margin of frequencies but, with "tshahsh" imperfection, in the numerical tv receiver, you have the signal at exact one frequency, if you move a little you lose the signal completely: signal or nothing.

I don't like when people refer to the Antikythera mechanism as a computer. And especially not when referenced as the first computer.

You can call it a calculator, but in the modern sense of of the term, it is not a computer. It has a fixed function.
In the old sense of the term, it isn't the first computer either. That would be whoever invented math, or I suppose the first person to do math for a living. The guy/gal who operated the Antikythera mechanism... They were a computer (in the old sense of the word. It was a job title. But, they also don't have a fixed function.)

I don't believe calling the Antikythera mechanism a calculator makes it less of a marvel. It is a wonderful tool and beyond the scope of the other technology available at the time.
Calling it a computer detracts from the computers we use today in the modern sense of the word, and the people in the old sense of the word.

Now, what to identify as the first computer device is debatable. There was some sewing machine that could be reprogrammed with different patterns. Idk if that offers enough of a different function though. I suppose if you fed that wave prediction device different inputs for a different task, you could definitely call that a computer. For example, maybe the first ever demo of noise canceling could be done via the same process.

Absolutely fascinating! One thing that merits clarification: Not all digital computers are based on the logic gates of type AND, OR and NOT. A set of logical operators (gate types) is called functionally complete if all other logical operators can be built from it. The sets {OR, NOT} and {AND, NOT} are both functionally complete, e.g. A AND B can be rewritten as NOT ((NOT A) OR (NOT B)).

In fact, the single element sets {NAND} and {NOR}, where A NAND B = NOT(A AND B) etc., are not only functionally complete but actually used in electronics… you may have heard of NAND flash and NOR flash memory, for instance.

That bit about the failure of the Norden bombsite over Japan isn't quite accurate. This may have been why the Norden site was as accurate as hoped in other situations, but over Japan the problem was that the B-29 bombers were flying so high they were having to drop their bombs through the jet-stream. No matter how accurate their aim was when they dropped the bombs, the bombs were scattered as they fell through the jet-stream. The only alternative was to fly low and at night.

I suspect the improvements in electronics, and perhaps even 3D printing of components will produce new and sophisticated analog machines.

Now, the “Paris Gun” did not use mechanical computers, as far as I know, but they had to calculate the Coriolis force as the projectile was in flight over 3 minutes and travelled through the stratosphere for most of it. The Norden Bomb Sight was not the first that calculated it …

And there are the TDC, Vorhalterechner and their mechanical computers submarines used to aim their torpedos — stuff like the torpedo getting to full speed, the turning radius onto the gyro course, the runtime before initialising the that turn, the parallax error because the periscope is 10s of metres away from the tubes and if you shoot at a point close to you the torpedo must make a sharper turn than for a target far away, everything else being similar …

Gyro sights were — comparatively — simple … but deadly.

Also, I have some doubts regarding your projectiles per plane — it is way too low from what I remember — and also you are probably ignoring the VT fuze (for “Variable Time”, a code name for this proximity fuze using miniature vacuum tubes) which alone dropped the projectiles per plane by at least an order of magnitude.

2:08 "Digital computers exploded onto the scene with the advent of solid-state transistors"
NO, valves were used beforehand, which could also be configured to process the 0s and 1s of binary. Before valves, computers used relays. Relays are physical switches with moving parts (magnets and coils) to switch electric circuits on and off. It's just that relays (a) were slower, (b) were noisier (c) required more electrical power (d) took up more space (e) were heavier and (f) were sometimes unreliable because of the physical moving parts.
The word "bug" (these days used to describe an error in a computer program) comes from a real bug (insect!) which, decades ago, might get into the moving parts, or into the circuit and short something out.

The problem isn't in what we know, it's in the various forms of what we don't. The first fault we found in digital was that binary decimals don't translate to fractions exactly, and errors rapidly propagate. It was resolved by emulating the manual calculations more precisely. Complex numbers still cause the drift. Next up, the implications of Nash' chaos theory, where null and zero are not the same thing, any more than indeterminate is. The inversion of that is orders of infinity.

"Digital computers are reaching their limit because transistors are nearly the size as atoms. Advancements in machine learning are straining the capabilities of digital computers."
But.

For a while now I have been wondering whether these limits couldn't be overcome by letting go of the notion that digital computers only can work with 0 (no signal) and 1 (signal). What if we introduce 2: 0 (no signal), 1 (weak signal) and 2 (strong signal)? It is obvious how this would work in transmitting data through fiber optic cables. In cds and dvds you would have to manifacture two types of bumps/pits for this to work. Even in Derek's digital lego computer at 1:15 you could have a 0 (large, well, let's call it "protrusion"), 1 (small protrusion) and 2 (no protrusion).

In the current 0-1 system, two bits can hold values from 0-3. In the 0-1-2 system, two bits can store values from 0-8. That's a 125% gain.

It was based on building circuits of resistors, capacitors, and inductors that were analogous to mechanical systems. Digital computers are hardly exact. There are large, important classes of problems for which digital computers invariably fail to give correct answers, and instead we're relegated to either computationally expensive estimations or no answer at all. This is a fact every data scientist is aware of.

Despite this, digital computers are still vastly superior to analog due to limitations of accuracy, environmental sensitivity, and durability when using any physical material to directly perform calculations.

Even digital signals are sent over physical media—electrical signals—and are subject to noise such as electromagnetic interference. Therefore, they're noisy just like analog signals at their most primitive form. Engineers have created systems to correct for that noise, such as error control codes. You experience digital noise in the form of latency, when digital signals need to be sent more than once if an error is detected. A long ethernet cable will have higher latency than a short one because the algorithms that detect noise have to re-send the signal more times in order to get it right.

Interesting.  I served aboard three different diesel electric submarines with one man control.  It was a large black box, about 3 feet cubed, which sat beside the "driver" sitting with a one man aircraft type control to control direction and depth, while the trim officer... dat would be me, sat beside him to adjust the buoyancy of the sub.  The one man control was fantastic at keeping the sub on course and depth.  One only had to dial on the depth and course, punch down the large button on top and the analogue box did the rest.  Our fire control computer for the torpedoes was, also, analogue.  We fed in the information about the target and it calculated the course and speed which it fed, directly, to the torpedoes right up to the moment they were fired.

Worked with a US Navy Gun Fire Control Computer for years in the mid 70's, before digital was common. They worked very well, but as explained, didn't always give the same exact answer twice in a row. Close, but not exact. That's why regular tests and calibrations were required. Since a projectile, unlike a guided missile, cannot change course in flight, having to consider ship pitch and roll, ship speed and direction, muzzle velocity, target altitude, range, direction and speed, time of flight and be able to predict where the projectile had to be to meet the target at a future position took a lot of timing motors, their associated gears and shafts, ballistics cams and their associated followers, synchros, resolvers, summing networks, indicator dials and hand crank inputs. My particular computer was about 6 ft tall, 2 ft deep and 10 ft wide. That could probably be replaced today by a computer the size of a typical tablet. Old systems like those have long been replaced by digital systems.. but the old engineering solutions were innovative and impressive.

When I started my career, 1980.  Analog controls were phasing out and digital just starting.  The digital computer we used was a custom design, 2, 16 bit shift registers into a single bit comparator, with carry.  We had 11 instructions, but only 4 were used mainly.  I asked why we moving towards digital when obliviously it was so rudimentary?  The answer, because we could change control equations with software, whereas changes to analog systems, always involved changes to hardware.   We had a group that modeled differential equations with this big patch board with op-amps, lags, leads and gains.  Analog controls are differential equation computers.

Another video which confuses Colossus with the Bombe Machine. At 16:20, Colossus is mentioned but the images are actually of the "computer" from the film "The Imitation Game" which didn't exist.

The fake machine was heavily based on the Turing-Welchman Bombe, an electro-mechanical device used to break Enigma encrypted messages.

Colossus was an electronic computing machine used to break Lorenz encrypted messages.

Working rebuilds of both the Bombe and Colossus can be seen in action at the National Museum of Computing at Bletchley Park, UK.

It's interesting that analog computing can be applied to so many types of physics..
In engineering, you learn that many physical systems (electrical circuits, optical systems, mechanical, fluid/hydraulic, aerodynamic, etc) often use very similar differential equations and expressions to solve the physics. That reasoning works in both directions. Common mathematical equations can therefore be "programmed" into a physical systems to compute. Just let the physics/nature do what it does, and the answer is extracted from what nature yields. Ideas ranging from "DNA computing" to Fourier optics might make very fast, or efficient, or simple or inexpensive special purpose "hardware" computers. (see "Fourier optical preprocessing in lieu of deep learning" by Muminov.)

I have operated analog computers for flight simulators. They were huge, ate tons of power, and somewhat cantankerous. They were also accurate and instantaneous. There was no such thing a a 'frame time'. All the calculations took place with little or no lag.
Operational amplifiers can perform all the mathematical functions, using just a few resistors and capacitors.

Servo systems simulated engine and flight functions. Watching a turboprop engine start was a joy. Half a dozen servos computing propeller speed, engine rpm, exhaust gas temperature, etc. The servos drove a series of potentiometers that were used as inputs to other calculations down the line. Switches and relays handled 'digital' functions; is the battery turned on? is the engine fuel switch on? Is the aircraft within range of a navigation aid.

Maintaining them was difficult, but being able to actually see what was (or wasn't) going on made it a lot easier.

Digital computers ultimate selling point is the versatility - the ability to compute basically anything with very simple components if given enough time - but certain types of tasks are become very hard to compute in this way. Some problems grow exponentially with the size of the input and effectively become unsolvable because of it simply because the time demand would make the answer useless by the time you got it. Even if the growth of computing power over time due to technological advancement is very large it can never fundamentally solve these issues. I imagine analogue computers might help fill in the gap in some of these specialized tasks - and ultimately may make sense as co-processors in a system.

In the early 70s, US Army A60-A1 tanks we had an analogue computer. The Gunner would index the round to be fired with a detent dial. There were only like 4 positions. There was a sight on both sides of the turret. The gunner would see a ghost and a real image in the sight. The Gunner would spin a wheel to bring the two images together. This would raise or lower the main gun. This was very accurate up to 1,500 yards. At distances up to a mile you had to make guesses as to windage.
We practiced this all the time as a tank team. we were to put the first round down range within five seconds of encountering a target and then every 3 seconds after that. That tank had to be standing still to do this. Subsequent US Tanks could fire on the move and could account for wind.

It's a shame you didn't mention the concept of "turing completeness" at the end. It's such a simple idea once grasped that's absolutely galaxy shattering in its implications: That any set of rules for manipulating data can simulate any other as long as both are capable of fulfilling Turing's definition of an automatic machine. This is the underlying principle behind modern day "general purpose computers" that can do basically anything we want them to, limited only by memory capacity and how long we'll wait for them to finish.

True general purpose computing is quite possibly one of the single greatest revolutions in human history, and one of the single most vital tools for the preservation of what we now consider basic liberty. Calculation, communication, and information are now infinitely distributed among everyone who possesses a general purpose computer and the root access to have it run whatever code they want.

In 1932 if a major corporation decided to tell the world that the genocide of the Holodomor wasn't real there was little the rest of us could do. Today anyone with a computer can speak to the world. The survivors of North Korean death camps and the Uighur genocide can make their voices heard to anyone who's willing to listen.

The problem with (most) digital computers is the simple limitation of oversimplification. We have had technology to process, read and write more than just a singular "bit". However, due to patents and associated overhead of new ideas, we continue to support old new-ways, instead of new old-ways or new new-ways. The concepts and devices are out there, but many are on shelves or locked in vaults or balancing on a work-bench.

The next level of progress has to be more organic and fluid in nature. Less confined, like digital and simply smart enough to realize that analog outputs are off and just correct them. (We do that every day, just walking around. We "know" what the level floor feels like, but we instantly adapt to legos, throw-rugs, spilled oil and sink-holes, without falling-over, most times. That is organic, AI-adaptive and analog computing, at it's lowest level of operation.)

One thing about the Nordon Bomb sight that isn't explained well here.  Yes inaccurate Manufactur can induce problems in the calculations but this was not the main reason for the campaign change in Japan.  Analog computers, also need All valuables included in order to be accurate.   When firing a gun your taught windage and the adjustments to combat the forces wind has on ballistic trajectory as well as elevation and gravity pulling the bullet to earth etc... In bombing with a Nordon bombsite all these factors were taken into consideration.  But at that time, the wind current we now know as "the jet stream" was unknown and played havoc with the precise computation of the bomb drops from high altitude above flack and fighter ranges.  It was this discovery and the cost and time to reengineer this factor that was not understood that led to the low altitude fire/carpet bombing decision.   The bomb site its self actually had very good results in Europe but the cost and time needed to understand the unknown variable parameters were not available in a time of conflict to make adjustments so to bring about the objectives of the war effort in ending the agression a new tactic was used.  This is the true cause of the change, not manufacturing deficiencies or design inaccuracies.

This girl/woman has studied psychology, and got her masters degree. (Why she turned out to be a DJ, well, I quest she just likes the job 😀).
But she once told this story over the radio. Apparently, when we go to bed, and we have a (hard) problem to solve and couldn’t let it rest until the last minute, our synapses keep on firing in our brains when we sleep. Our subconsciousness is still trying to solve the issue, even when we are sleeping. And every once-in-a-while, this results in the answer in a dream, when we are asleep. This resulted in the phrase: “let me sleep on it”, when we have an issue to solve, and can’t give an answer right away!

Regulators on Diesel engines, are often way more complicated than expected.

Not only regulators for revolutions, but almost any kind of regulation can be done, with very high precision and extreme reliability. They easily run for 25-50 years, with little maintenance.

The obvious advantage is, it can’t be hacked, blow a fuse, or need any kind of external handling. They simply run by themselves.

Extreme shaking, even a nuclear attack, and they just keep on fully functioning.

Many jet engines use a sophisticated hydromechanical analog computer for their fuel control.

It can consider inputs like air temperature and pressure along with engine RPM and power lever angle to schedule the appropriate amount of fuel through a complex mechanical system built from simple machines like levers and flyweights. There's even "3D" camshafts that combine axial and rotational inputs into a single output.

Granted, metering a particular amount of fuel for a steady-state power level is pretty straightforward, but when you need to accelerate or decelerate without surging or flaming-out, that's where you need the computer.

Of course, modern engines have digital computers to do the work, but even those are usually working in tandem with the hydromechanical system. The digital system may augment and trim the mechanical system, but the mechanical system is fully capable of doing everything on it's own.

I was once an INS/WRCS technician in the USAF. As late as the early 1990's, navigation computers and weapons release computers on some military jets were analog. They worked with servos that operated much like that old Greek artifact. On the F4-E (I had the pleasure of working on the old birds just before they were retired) the inertial navigation system fed the weapons release computer system attitude and velocity info which was used to automatically calculate release times of small bombs. It kept them from having to be dive bombers... (check out "toss bombing" on Wikipedia). The tech was pretty darned cool. And it was amazing to learn the theory of operation. There were a LOT of analog signal wires in the navigation system of an F-4.

The advantage with an Analog Electronic CPU is that if it takes 1 microsecond to multiply two 8-bit variables, it'll theoretically still take 1 microsecond to multiply two ∞-bit variables assuming the voltage rises instantly; of course that doesn't happen IRL but it'd still be so unimaginably faster than a digital CPU.

Now if we paired an Analog CPU with a digital storage like an SSD, It'd never even "slop" or accumulate errors because everything will be stored digitally.

Its only problem is that power rises when doing operations on bigger variables, so you traded your consistent power consumption with consistent performance time. I see that as a complete win to be honest because you consume power that you only need at a time.

Little disadvantage: Might need a digital CPU to translate from analog to digital storage which may cause a bottleneck but since it'll be a specific-purposed CPU, then it'll be way faster. And we can always come up with creative ways to convert analog information to digital information instantly with no much circuitry.

I'm getting a little tired of people calling anything mechanical that seems a little ahead of its time a computer. By the logic used the transmission on my car is a computer, and it's not. Computers have a CPU, "central processing unit" that can be "programmed" and more importantly generically programmed and therein lies the difference.

These other devices you could sometimes loosely call a calculator but an actual computer by any useful definition you can't really do so.

To clarify, general mechanical devices that you see of the past are not really programmable. They're much like the transmission on my car although my car's transmission is arguably slightly programmable because you can change the gear ratios to get different outputs "from the same input" which is key to being programmable but it really isn't a computer, it's just a slightly more complex than normal mechanical device. Having a lot of gears that change ratios of output and input, or just a lot gears mimicking planetary motion is not a computer. It's a fun device, a pretty complex device of gears for sure, but complex does not equal computer.

You could have a device with 100,000 gears and it still wouldn't be a computer, it would just be a device with a sh*t load of gears whirring around unless it has a few key additional attributes, like Alan Turning's original machine which if I remember correctly was mechanical but most importantly generically programmable.

The problem is that once you loosen the term computer to start including such devices the term becomes essentially meaningless because a seesaw with a sliding midpoint (perhaps to adjust for different weighted people on each end) could be argued to to suit the definition -- it's just get silly/ridiculous at that point.

Many years ago I thought that the combination of digital and analog computers could be useful. The digital computer would be in charge, setting the parameters for the analog system, e.g. resistance, capacitance, voltage, etc. Even “material” characteristics, like changing lengths, weights, etc. Or to design components to be used for mechanical systems.
You could configure the analog system(s) for single optimized functions or allow multiple configurations as the system evolved, like refining computations from coarse to fine as you got closer to a (possible) solution. Feedback from the process can be used to make continuous adjustments, monitor slop and look for other pending inaccuracies or failures.

Similar to digital neural nets, you oscillate the input variables and measure the relative changes in output, then use this information for stochastic gradient descent (essentially following the grad function to the global minima mathematically speaking). Eniac is actually a mechanical computer done with rings of tubes as circular shift registers in analog for mechanical gears.  It is digital in a sense that Babbage's machine was digital, but an analogue of a mechanical computer.  It looks a lot like the Mark computers done by Howard Aiken.   (Aiken also said there was a Babbage machine at Harvard he had seen).   The first true digital electonic computer predated Eniac, it was the Atanastov-Berry machine.  However, as I heard the story,  John von Neumann who was the directory of scientists moved Atanastov to work on some sort of audio or sonar project.  This left his machine, which was a true digital computer, gathering dust, while the Moore School guys were wiring tubes in rings to turn like gears, and lots of them.

Perhaps it's just the way my mind works (I learn what I need in order to understand/do what is currently beyond me), but a good math teacher could show me this, then work backwards by explaining (as far back as necessary) each concept, bring it forward, repeat, and in a few months or so I'd have an understanding and useful grasp of all the foundational concepts better and faster than being taught by the usual methods. Theories memorized, but not immediately applied, are less than useful.

There is something so ironic about this video. The beginnings of analog computers required a lot of time to both design and build. Sketching and drawing out components were the basis of eventually building these analog machines. As there were no digital TV's, computers, phones, laptops, etc. these people grew up with no distractions, and if so inclined could spend hours by candle light thinking and sketching, day after day, or working on mathematical concepts and problems.

The eventual development of digital computers has led us to a plethora of distractions. TV, gaming, watching Netflix, etc. has taken us far away from just sitting down and thinking, day after day. Lights have made it easy to stay up too late, be tired, and feel lousy the next day. Far too tired to think or we would fall asleep doing so.

You have to wonder what this world would look like without the distractions, especially for entertainment. How many hours have we all spent in the past 10 years doing something that doesn't ever lead to anything of real value. Now, think of all that time spent thinking, being inspired, sketching an idea, etc. to help solve a world problem. Kinda blows you away.

I mean... modern computers do use some analog components to speed up data transfers or store more data in one digital signal.
GDDR6X Memory for example (used in the RTX 3080, 3080 Ti and 3090 by Nvidia) is using different Voltage levels to encode 2 bits in one clock cycle.
SSDs go even further storing up to 4 bits per cell (found in QLC SSDs), by writing the initial data at different voltage levels.
It's not quite analog as the machines of days past, but it is analog as old analog TV is analog, except that the voltage is carrying multiple digital signals...

And yes analog computers will absolutely have uses. There are numerous cases in which digital computers falter, notably in cases where fine detail is required, because each additional doubling of accuracy requires a doubling of the entire detail of the system. With analog computing, we can factor for the amount of needed detail more accurately, as the function being used can be tailored to provide extreme levels of detail without having to resort to the brute force equivalent used in the digital realm. We'll no longer be in the realm of "higher clock speeds, more cores, larger caches, and lower delays between components" and instead in the realm of smarter components that are able to conform more cleanly to use cases. This will hopefully provide the solution to the ever-growing "internet of things" issue, where every device and its mother currently needs a digital microprocessor in it to interface with other devices.

And of course, this is all closely paralleled by the similar concepts in the world of music technology. We have gone from physical/mechanical objects to electromechanical to purely electric to discrete electric to the present era of combined discrete and analog electronics (and some physical things like reverb tanks still, as well as all "traditional" instruments and other microphoned things). I hope to see the trend of ever-shrinking components applied to physical and analog methodologies, such that we have microscopic things that are able to handle ranges of values. The holy grail would be to get the operational ranges of physical, mechanical, and analog into the form factor of digital. Let's hope that's where we're headed.

Fun fact... one of the biggest secrets of WW2 equal to the atomic bomb, was the proximity fuze.  Which detonated a flack gun projectile in close proximity to an aircraft, or even altillery projectiles close to the ground causing maximum effect, instead of on the ground minimizing effect.  A proximity fuze uses radio signals that reduce in frequency as the projectile approaches an object, magnetic and sonar systems were tried and all failed due to the violence of the forces encountered as a round is fired.  As for the calculations these computers did for anti aircraft purposes against dive bombers, the truth is the computers did nothing, and it was so secret that even anti aircraft gunners had no idea that the dial to adjust the altitude at which the round detonated was fake.  Because it was actually the proximity fuze that caused the detonation of the round, and not the adjustment of the altitude dial.

When I joined the Navy in 1971, they still operated analog computers in some of their fire control systems. An entrance exam showed some simple gear output questions. I worked on a Norden system that was a true hybrid. It had a few analog computers that operated on gear ratios, electronic pots, accurate voltage references, relays, shaft encoders, etc. to a digital computer that had vacuum tubes, early 1960's transistors, late 1950's developed magnetic core memory, magnetic drum memory with about 2 dozen read/write heads in it. Not an integrated circuit chip in the whole system. This fit inside an attack aircraft that operated off of aircraft carriers plus ordinance and 2 crew. This unlike the aforementioned bombsight, actually got the job done. Yet these break down and needs constant maintenance and like the airframe it is attached to gets old and outdated.

At both the outer edge and inner edge it instead cuts down sharply & narrowly at just over the width of the horizontal bar. This way when the horizontal bar in it's encasement is sitting in this spot the case fits down in and bar slides down in with a little extra space but the encasement can't shift forwards & backwards. The top half of cylindrical structure has same groove but no extended ridge going further towards center. Fill the rest of the rectangular grooves with duplicates of the electric generator construct. Now carefully position top of cylindrical structure in place and screw it to bottom section. Now position the motor segment with the vertical bar that has discs on it in center of cylindrical construct so the disc is lined up perfectly underneath the inner ridge that has the flat ring of high permeability material fastened to it. Now you can duplicate this whole setup and stack it for more electrical output. (The only thing that would need to be duplicated with the motor & vertical bar setup is for you to add another disc with magnets embedded in it, higher up on the vertical bar you are already using). When you turn motor on the discs will spin and the magnetic fields on them will only interact with the discs on the horizontally positioned bars when the magnetic field lines go through the small openings in the high permeability material. Since those openings are lined up with the edge of the discs connected to the horizontally positioned bars, it will force them to spin, effectively generating lots of electrical current. Just make sure to let enough of that current pump energy into the 1 motor you are using to run things, and the rest of the electric current is over unity. If you are still wondering how this could end up being over unity, the answer is simple. The device exploits magnetic field effects connected to the vertically positioned bar connected to the motor to have them do all the extra work so the motor does not have to. And since the magnets are exerting there force upwards while the bar spins around sideways, the motor won't be getting a detrimental amount of push back. This design invented by ☯AMA☯

Another interesting and not that well-known thing about the first computers is that even when thigns started to firmly shift towards digital, they were not always binary. There used to be computer which did not compute only in terms of 0 and 1 (which is the thing everyone always assume), but worked with more voltage levels (not just "tension" or "no tension", but an actual scale of possible tensions). It was eventually recognized that those systems were more difficult to stabilize (it's easier to distinguish "tension" from "no tension" than "tension A" from "tension B" for various values).
But I think it's interesting to think about how today "computers only understand 1s and 0s" has become an obvious universal fact, but it was not always the case, even for digital computers.

Technically our computers do confuse 1s and 0s at a certain point in time it’s known as “hazard error” it’s do to the fact that when the state changes let’s say from 0 to 1 the signal doesn’t just magically transform to 1 but rather continuously increases to 1. And in between the 0 and 1 is where our computers fail to calculate correctly :) also we don’t need all three “and”, “or” and “not” we only need either “and” and “not” or “or” and “not” according to de Morgan’s law :)

When I started in Engineering school, there were generic purpose electric analog computers. I never got to use them, because they were phased out before I got to that level, but I think they were used by students of differential equations to prove their models. Instead of coding, they worked by patching components with wires, such that they could combine the effects of different analog elements, to obtain an output curve to the input they provided. Something to an electronic version of the tidal wave prediction machine, but configurable to different sequences depending on the patching.

The Norden bomb sight was NOT highly classified and it was technically less sophisticated than a contemporary product from Sperry. The Norden bomb sight was technically inferior, but a commercial success, because the manufacturers of the Norden bomb sight could actually tell legislators and procurement officers about its existence. There was even a Norden bomb sight inspired toy that allowed children to bomb Japanese ships (this toy was revived in the 1970s, but it was delivering rescue supplies, not bombs). The advertising blitz allowed the Norden bomb sight to get far more orders than it deserved.

Not that it was not good, at all, but it was not as good as the Sperry system that actually was highly classified.

Analog is used in the sense of "proportional" here, not in the sense of "analogy". What makes it analogue is that it uses measurable quantities, with lengths and ratios, rather than discrete counted quantities. A slide rule is analog, an abacus is digital. It has nothing directly to do with analogies: when you use an abacus to conduct a census you are also making an analogy between groups of people in a population and the beads on the abacus. Don't get confused by etymology.

I've got several slide rules in my desk as I write this. There is something very beautiful about them. Many aircraft still carry EB6 computers as spares, essentially a specialized slide rule for the complex calculations including wind, speed and bearing and produce answers directly. They are simple, reliable and immune to electrical or magnetic issues.

I had a lab exercise to simulate a control system stability with an analog computer.  The analog computer was built using vacuum tube op-amps.  Their signal range was +/- 100 V.  A bit later, where I worked, my boss had also earlier used the same analog computer and we started discussing if we could build our own, but with recently introduced semiconductor op-<del>amps.  Well, that discussion resulted in a task for me to design and build one.  What I ended putting together was a box with 10 op-amps, a bunch of stackable resistors and capacitors and a few special units,  and a panel with banana sockets for the stackable components.  All along with amplifier symbols on the panel.  The signal range was reduced to just +/</del> 10 V.  My boss was  soon happily simulating not only his control systems, but also extrusion and cooling processes for high voltage cable insulations.  That was just before I got transferred to another division of the company, where new challenges were waiting me in a new R&D lab.  So I myself never had the opportunity of really learning to use "my" analog computer in anything but simple servo loop simulations (optimizations).

Fascinating.  I took the very last analog computer class offered by UC Berkeley.  This was the mid-70's.  All patch boards and op-amps (tube-type, of course).  My senior project was to compare the output of a model rocket flight simulator I'd patched up to a digital version that I had written (in FORTRAN IV) as a sophomore, and a real world analysis of a rocket flight using an Estes Cineroc movie camera..  I've had a soft spot for analog computers ever since.  Glad to see they are not only not forgotten, but may be making a comeback.

I know that the border is quite fluent, but there is quite a distinction between computers and calculators. The main difference is that you can program the computer, which means you can change what it is doing (the algorithm). And that is a game changer - machine is no longer dedicated to do one task, you can reprogram your machine to do something completely different, we even use computers to design and build new computers. I don't want to belittle awesomeness of those analog machines from the past, but their designers have just a fraction of brilliancy of people who designed and programmed modern computers. It's maybe just because nowadays computers are so common and hard to understand how they actually work that we forget how marvellously crafted machines they are - you can literally pick any part of software or hardware of modern computer and talk for hours about all the little smart trick were used to build them.

I wanted to point out that Analog is not a synonym for Continuous and Digital is not a synonym for Discrete.
In fact there are four types of possible signals:-
1. Continuous Analog
2. Discrete Analog
3. Continuous Digital
4. Discrete Digital

Continuous and Discrete represents the signal parameter on Time axis.
Analog and Digital represents the signal parameter on Amplitude axis.

Growing up reading Asimov ( I Robot etc.) in his Sci Fi universe, Analog had won the battle.  His Positronic AI was great for the imagination. We see a world made of things, and try to count them, but the relationship between things is just as important if not more, and that is what analog is all about.

The misery of hell will be so great that no one will want to be there. They will be weeping and gnashing their teeth (Matthew 8:12). Between their sobs, they will not speak the words “I want this.” They will not be able to say amid the flames of the lake of fire (Revelation 20:14), “I want this.” “The smoke of their torment goes up forever and ever, and they have no rest, day or night” (Revelation 14:11). No one wants this.

When there are only two choices, and you choose against one, it does not mean that you want the other, if you are ignorant of the outcome of both. Unbelieving people know neither God nor hell. This ignorance is not innocent. Apart from regenerating grace, all people “suppress the truth in unrighteousness” (Romans 1:18).
The person who rejects God does not know the real horrors of hell. This may be because he does not believe hell exists, or it may be because he convinces himself that it would be tolerably preferable to heaven. But whatever he believes or does not believe, when he chooses against God, he is wrong about God and about hell. He is not, at that point, preferring the real hell over the real God. He is blind to both. He does not perceive the true glories of God, and he does not perceive the true horrors of hell.

So when a person chooses against God and, therefore, de facto chooses hell — or when he jokes about preferring hell with his friends over heaven with boring religious people — he does not know what he is doing. What he rejects is not the real heaven (nobody will be boring in heaven), and what he wants is not the real hell, but the tolerable hell of his imagination.
When he dies, he will be shocked beyond words. The miseries are so great he would do anything in his power to escape. That it is not in his power to repent does not mean he wants to be there. Esau wept bitterly that he could not repent (Hebrews 12:17). The hell he was entering into he found to be totally miserable, and he wanted out. The meaning of hell is the scream: “I hate this, and I want out.”

Thrown into Hell

What sinners want is not hell but sin. That hell is the inevitable consequence of unforgiven sin does not make the consequence desirable. It is not what people want — certainly not what they “most want.” Wanting sin is no more equal to wanting hell than wanting chocolate is equal to wanting obesity. Or wanting cigarettes is equal to wanting cancer.
Beneath this misleading emphasis on hell being what people “most want” is the notion that God does not send people to hell. But this is simply unbiblical. God certainly does send people to hell. He does pass sentence, and he executes it. Indeed, worse than that. God does not just send, he throws. “If anyone’s name was not found written in the book of life, he was thrown into the lake of fire” (Revelation 20:15; cf. Mark 9:47; Matthew 13:42; 25:30).

The reason the Bible speaks of people being thrown into hell is that no one will willingly go there once they see what it really is. No one standing on the shore of the lake of fire jumps in. They do not choose it, and they will not want it. They have chosen sin. They have wanted sin. They do not want the punishment. When they come to the shore of this fiery lake, they must be thrown in.

Jesus’s Blazing Words

When someone says that no one is in hell who doesn’t want to be there, they give the false impression that hell is within the limits of what humans can tolerate. It inevitably gives the impression that hell is less horrible than Jesus says it is.

We should ask, “How did Jesus expect his audience to think and feel about the way he spoke of hell?” The words he chose were not chosen to soften the horror by being accommodating to cultural sensibilities. He spoke of a “fiery furnace” (Matthew 13:42), and “weeping and gnashing of teeth” (Luke 13:28), and “outer darkness” (Matthew 25:30), and “their worm [that] does not die” (Mark 9:48), and “eternal punishment” (Matthew 25:46), and “unquenchable fire” (Mark 9:43), and being “cut in pieces” (Matthew 24:51).

These words are chosen to portray hell as an eternal, conscious experience that no one would or could ever want if they knew what they were choosing. Therefore, if someone is going to emphasize that people freely choose hell, or that no one is there who doesn’t want to be there, surely he should make every effort to clarify that, when they get there, they will not want this.
Surely the pattern of Jesus — who used blazing words to blast the hell-bent blindness out of everyone — should be followed. Surely, we will grope for words that show no one, no one, no one will want to be in hell when they experience what it really is. Surely everyone who desires to save people from hell will not mainly stress that it is wantable or chooseable, but that it is horrible beyond description — weeping, gnashing teeth, darkness, worm-eaten, fiery, furnace-like, dismembering, eternal punishment, “an abhorrence to all flesh” (Isaiah 66:24).

I thank God, as a hell-deserving sinner, for Jesus Christ my Savior, who became a curse for me and suffered hellish pain that he might deliver me from the wrath to come. While there is time, he will do that for anyone who turns from sin and treasures him and his work above all.

- extracted from an article by John Piper.

My favourite analog computers somewhat pre date WW1 and were the rangefinders and fire control tables on warships that integrated the firing ships motions, forward, roll, pitch and yaw, with the target's range, bearing and speed to aim the gun batteries and achieve hits against moving targets at 10,000+ yard ranges, or in HMS Warspite's case, with Radar assist in WW2, almost 15 miles.

Also the WW1 warships made early use of electrical signaling from the central fire director station to the guns to set the individual turret rotation and gun elevation to fire on the correct target solution almost like a stepper motor. When I was learning to be an engineer back in the early '70s, analog computers were on the way out the door. Large-scale integration was beginning, and Moore's Law was a new concept that my professor's predicted was going to revolutionize computers.

Fifty years later I am retired after a career in digital computing, and now I find that analog is making a comeback. I am looking forward to part 2; I know enough about analog computer that I can anticipate some of the application for which they will be useful. I suspect the improvements in electronics, and perhaps even 3D printing of components will produce new and sophisticated analog machines.

Makes me wish I was 20 again, so I could have a second career in analog!

Mechanical analogue computation devices are rare and (IMO) are not coming back unless it's on the nanoscale. But Electronic analogue devices never went away. At this point in time a generic digital CPU is probably cheaper, but if you need it an analogue (or mixed analogue/digital) ASIC is often used. There are even FPGA devices with analogue components; though usually very few as signal/noise ratios will be a pain.

#17:10 Strictly speaking, you only need one operation as you can do any logical operation on any number of inputs by combining 2-input NAND (NOT AND) gates or by combining 2-input NOR (NOT OR) gates. The problem with analog computers is that they need separate machanisms to calculate all the different processes. This makes them impractical for smaller devices like phones and smartwatches which are prone to shaking making digital the ideal ones. With AI coming over, it just makes the digital computers choose newer ways to calculate complex functions efficiently.

This makes me think about MRI imaging.

It uses analog equipment to collect analog data, converts that to digital data, Then performs Fourier transforms and stores the data. We then run an inverse Fourier transform and display the values, giving a digital representation of the anatomy.

Many advances in image quality recently have been converting the analog to digital ASAP, to limit noise. Now they are even using AI to remove noise..

It makes me wonder if it would be possible to create an analog AI for removing noise, and forgo the analog to digital conversion, giving the AIgorithims early access to the data, then project this data into an analog storage medium...

Fun science fiction for now I suppose.

C'mon man so many wrong assumptions. You should research it more. Moore's law might be dead in its original form, but scaling is far from over. Transistors are no where near as small as atoms. State-of-the-art CMOS manufacturing node is still 7nm (for TSMC and Samsung and equivalent of that 10nm that Intel just managed to reach a few months ago). The only commercial products in 5nm node are Apple's M1 chips so far (there are plenty in the pipe, but not yet on the market). So we are gonna wait at least for a year or two (specially due to current bottlenecks in production) before 5nm becomes a norm. And TSMC has already 3nm in advanced state with a promising yield. Moreover, each node has many iterations where each iteration improves power consumption yielding higher Hz/W performance.
What we know for certain is that current scaling is not gonna stop until at least 1nm node. That is 10 years from now and probably a factor of 15-30x in performance compared to the current 7nm node.

I heavily dispute these numbers of 90 rounds to take out an aircraft, the fact is AA fire was mostly ineffective throughout ww2 in actually taking out aircraft, and only had the function of making aircraft deploy their bomb load at an earlier, higher altitude and thus decreasing their accuracy. Even for German bombers, roughly 90% made it back home during all but the final weeks of the war, most that didn't were taken out by fighter aircraft or fuel shortages. A more accurate number would be for every tonnage of aircraft brought down by flack, 15 tons of anerican AA ammunition would be used up, and 18 tons for German AA, But again, its not the metric for success, since the AA's job is not to take out aircraft. It is also noteworthy that the German AA was far more effective throughout the war due to their heavy relying on synchronised strategic firing. In essence they would fire as a battery in front of a formation in a screen, making aircraft have to fly through a big square of exploding flack. Even if every shot itself was less accurate and in fact not even aimed at a specific aircraft, an entire formation would be peppered with fragments of a bunch of rounds all at once. Leading for a far larger psychological toll on pilots and crew.

comment_text: In the '90s, as a personal investigation, I designed and built a "Sort-Of Analog Computer" that used cross bar and cross point switches to interconnect a collection of analog circuits such as summing amplifiers, 'differencing' amplifiers, log amplifiers, anti-log amplifiers and a number of other analog circuits designed for single-purpose function. The switches served the part of circuit wiring. A digital program configured the analog circuits into any algorithm or multivariable equation to suit. This gave you the ability to input many variable values simultaneously while generating an output in real-time. The only processing 'speed limit' was determined by the slew rates of the amplifier components used ... I used only generic op amps for the project because they cost only pennies per package. Such a simple way to perform complex tasks ... potentially puts parallel digital processing to shame.

Digital computers are not really all that robust to noise. I am a student of mathematics with a minor in informatics, and let me tell you: Avoiding propagating errors is half of what I do.
In data transmission (especially from device to device, but even only from RAM to CPU) there is a very real chance of a bit flipping. This usually is due to induction in the very tightly packed cables. This is mitigated by using checksums. But if our computers didn't have that problem, they could be faster and store more data, while staying as reliable.
Also in numerical computations you run into problems because you have only a limited amount of space to save any intermediate result. You will have to round, and this can lead to huge errors further in. There are some algorithms, that work beautifully by hand, but can't be implemented on a digital computer because of this.

The first example I ever saw of an analogue computer was in a towed, sonar seabed profiler manufactured by the Canadian company Huntec. Their profiler was secured to the ship by a long armoured cable which (naturally) passed any wave movement affecting the ship, directly onto the image being produced by the profiler. Huntec's answer was an accelerometer inside their profiler, the output of which was fed into two integrators, which translated the measured acceleration of the profiler into displacement. This displacement was then applied to the sonar signal in the form of an analogue delay, which (amazingly) removed the wave movement.

The electronics in that device were simply amazing (like a Swiss watch), and I still take my hat off to the small team who designed and built it!

Derek - this video assumes a "computer" is just a calculator. A modern day digital computer isn't a calculator, but a turing complete machine. Its a machine that can execute any general purpose program along with a memory. Calling the 3 gears machine a computer isn't accurate. I would instead call it an analog calculator.

The modern computer is an electronic implementation of something called "von neumann machine". The gear machine isn't that.

Digital computing is a way to abreviate small closed systems behaviour and create algorythms that make for a versatile tool simulating conditions that solve specific problems. So, in the past it was pure obseration analogy, now we have digital tools to help speed up analog systems analisis and simplify the analogy. The limit would be quantum phisics, the most "analog" of systems. No sum of logical mathematical interactions that we have now can reach that analogy.
