My specialty & favorite job in the Marines was working on our Aviation 8-day Clocks.  If I could’ve stayed in that job for the rest of my life, I would’ve been happy, just working with the gears & springs.  But that’s not how jobs in the USMC work, even if I’d re-enlisted I would’ve had to pick up a B-billet, by the time I was done with that I would’ve been picking up SNCO rank, meaning the closest I’d ever get to it again would be another re-enlistment down the line when I might have become a supervisor for Marines who worked on them, and I might have been able to do a little tinkering on the side.  Also, you can’t get out of the military and just get a job repairing clocks & watches - hell, you can’t get that job at all anywhere except for a few special areas.  So instead I leaned into my programming & electronics experience, the former from before I joined & the latter of which was supplemented by the other duties of a 6423, and worked in IT for the ensuing decade & a half.  The possibility that all of my skills may be becoming relevant in the next wave of technological innovation & development is exciting… but it’s probably all too far off for me to really get in on it, considering my age.  Still very interesting to see where this goes.

Virtual Machines versus Physical Machines. I really like this episode! Honest, but I dont like the "Analog" header versus "Digital" computing.
Reason why?: A Turing Machine was an Analog, I.E. Physical Machine, a Ford Factory is a physical machine. The program on paper is Virtual or Digital. A program contains many detailed virtual machines (functions).

Now, A Virtual Machine can exist in super position across multiple machines with a disconnection or loss of its parent physical machine. The same is with a process routine written on paper. A physical machine can ONLY exist in one place and in one sequence of states we can observe.

If I copy and paste the same program or Virtual machine across many Physical machines, observers can witness either individualized outputs or the same output across the many Physical Machines.

A Digital Computer like a RAM gate is considered Digital, but a chip that performs an Analog Process with a signal in one physical location in one sequence of states.
A Program or Virtual Machine is completely Digital and can exist across multiple platforms in multiple states.

"Digital" implies that electricity is involved with Electromagnetic signaling. "Analog" implies no Electromagnetic signaling but the Speaker built a RAM Gate out of Legos, so I question if the definition. With enough of those put together, you get a Turing machine, and you can crank it with animal on a treadmill or with Electricity. Either way, the Physical RAM gate is in one state, physical. One can write a program of a RAM gate and put across Ten computers, and it is in multiple states, untethered from the parent physical machine that created it.

You're making the difference between digital and analog computers by the difference that they either are discrete or continuous and also that they either work with physical parameters or just with symbols.
In most cases that absolutely makes sense. But the abacus is an interesting hybrid here. It's not analog because it's discrete but it's also not really digital because it works with physical parameters.
When the result of your calculation is five, there will physically be five of those beads in a certain position and not just an arrangement of beads that represent the number five. But even while you could cut a bead in half, that's not how it's meant to be used and you won't be able to work with all real numbers.
However, I still think that the abacus is digital. I think it makes much more sense to focus on the question of whether something is continuous or discrete.

Always excited to hear about analogue computers. (Also love your animation style!) My graduate studies are related to a form of analogue computing, namely analogue signal processing. In fact, my master's project was conceived as an implementation of RF Fourier transform. My introductory optics textbook included a discussion of optical implementation of Fourier transform. That became the inspiration for my master's project. Yet I had never heard of Kelvin's tide calculator. I don't think the Computer History Museum in Mountain View, CA even cited it. CHM has illustrated or displayed prototypes or replicas of several historical analogue computers. There is even one historical electric analogue computer. But I didn't notice a tide calculator. As I lamented before, CHM should be more aptly named DCHM, for “Digital Computer History Museum”, as it did not cover some other historically significant analogue computers that I had known.

While analogue computers at large have been fading, the field of analogue signal processing has become commoditised. The lowly SAW filter is one of the most ubiquitous devices in today’s “digital” world, for example. (Every analogue filter beyond your basic LC filter is an analogue computer. But the sophistication of today’s SAW filters is beyond imagination.) Similarly, aspheric lens is another example of analogue computer.
So Lord Kelvin single handedly invented analog mpeg3 encoder / decoder. Ok, without the psyco-acoustic model baked in, but hey, still impressive.

SURPRISE !!!!
Our brain is NOT digital.
Nor is it a computer.
The brain is a 'simple' (it's not simple) analogue device (antikythera) comparable to early analogue movie-making equipment = analogue cameras + analogue audio equipment + analogue projector projecting analogue pictures back onto a screen.
Our brain doesn't add & subtract numbers - its a virtual reality machine. It operates on all of the analogue information being delivered to it via the senses - analogue images; analogue sounds etc, etc. AND IN PRECISELY THE SAME MANNER AS EARLY ANALOGUE MOVIE-MAKING EQUIPMENT managed the job, AFTER MASHING (integrating) IT ALL TOGETHER OUR BRAIN PROJECTS THIS INTEGRATED SIGNAL IN A RE-ANIMATED & WHOLLY ANALOGUE FORM onto a screen. Literally.
The integration of all of the different kinds of (analogue) information pouring into our central processor, as they arrive from all of the different sensory modalities, requires no small amount of "antikytheria-ing" (as I choose to put it after watching this sea-change video).

A lot of people (especially in the military) are really interested in developing the tech, so there's a lot of funding out there for it these days. I'm working on an Air Force funded MURI called CEREBRAL (Cross-disciplinary Electronic-ionic Research Enabling Biologically Realistic Autonomous Learning). Bit hokey of a name, but the idea behind the project is really interesting. Essentially we're trying to accelerate the development of these analog semiconductor circuit elements called "memristors", "memdiodes", etc. If we can work out the kinks and make the tech scalable and affordable, it could really revolutionize machine learning and computing in general.

This let ENIAC be seen as the early pioneer, when it was actually trailing behind.

One question that I have been asking of anyone who has any involvement with quantum computers is what fundamentally is the difference between a quantum computer and an analog computer? I clearly understand the difference between how they are implemented and the theory of how they work, however I suspect that they are probably very similar in regard to their utility - I.E. how they are applied to solving a particular problem.

I have often thought that if the analogy between these two computers could be demonstrated then there would be a case for diverting R&D funding from expensive quantum computer development into modern analog computer development which will certainly be considerably more cost effective and more likely to produce useful hardware in a considerably shorter development time.

I dispute the popular claims (exaggerations) that the Antikythera device is a mechanical computer.
It is an orrery. Essentially a mechanical clock - it "tells time" in terms of planetary orbits instead of in hours and minutes.
It cannot intrinsically "compute" anything, it cannot accept different inputs to produce different outputs, it cannot be "reprogrammed" for any other task without a complete reconstruction.

Spent a huge chunk of my sophomore years in 2001 on learning 741 OP-amp, professors told us it was used for making computers and calculators during the 60s. But later the entire ecosystem of analog computers were completely replaced by boolean logic circuits. But some type of computations, especially numerical integration/differentiation can be done really really fast and quite accurately on a very simple 741 OP-amp configurations (even you can make one now, just order the components over ebay and won't cost more than 10$ with batteries) but for some reason people don't use that technology anymore. Would be really excited to see how they are coming back. I'm hyped for the next installments.

@2:09 "Digital computers exploded onto the scene with the advent of solid state transistors"
NOT SO
IBM 650 First installed in 1954, "the first mass-produced computer in the world" Wikipedia
IBM 700 series (701,702,704,709) - at about the same time, all using vacuum tube logic. The 704 was introduced in 1954. The 704 failed on the average every 4 hours - Wikipedia. (vacuum tubes, remember?)
IBM 7040,7044,7090, 7094 were basically equivalent to the 704 and 709 (704T for a transistorized 704, and 709T for a transistorized 709). The first 7090 was installed in 1959.
The first working transistor was built in 1947, but was obviously not commercially viable until much later.
NB My first use of a digital computer was on an IBM 7094 at Purdue University in 1964. My first full-time job was using an IBM 7044 at Purdue University's High Energy Physics research group.

I've always disliked referring to the Antikythera mechanism as a computer. Don't get me wrong, it is objectively an analogue computer. And it is absolutely fascinating. My problem is the sensationalism behind referring to it as an "ancient computer". It's just too... clickbait-y, for lack of a better term. I suppose what I'm getting at is that it's a pretty well known discovery, relatively speaking in terms of the layman, of which I'd consider myself in this field. But I know that it would be significantly less known/recognized if it were instead referred to as simply an orrey artifact, or an ancient tool for track astronomical positions. Again, I am not arguing against it being a computer, because it absolutely is. I suppose I just hate flashy science. People tend to love flashy science, not real science. And these days I find it not only annoying, but dangerous in a way.

Gray Code is a form of binary that uses a different method of incrementing from one number to the next. With Gray Code, only one bit changes state from one position to another. This feature allows a system designer to perform some error checking (i.e., if more than one bit changes, the data must be incorrect).

As a retired software engineer with 50+ years experience and foundational hardware experience including analog processes, I can say that, IMHO there's nothing that can be done via analog computing that cannot be done better, faster, more accurately and with repeatable results via digital software. It's all about wrapping your mind around the problem and paying appropriate attention to details. ALSO, there's the matter of precision which can be obtained via floating point numbers which can be much more precise than analog signals and still yield repeatable results. In point of fact, it is not so easy to introduce unpredictability or randomness in digital software, but it has been done for simulation and wargaming purposes, all of which I have done.

The problem with analog computers, is the problem of noise. The continuous nature of analog computers means that they are sensitive to many forms of noise generated by mechanical or electrical errors in device. This noise can be eliminated using digital processing, this is why digital processing has become the dominate form of numerical processing. Analog computers are really only useful for simple calculations, where the number of computational step is limited, and thus the noise can be controlled. Once you try to put millions or billions of computational steps together in an analog system, the noise can easily overwhelm the system, and you get a very expensive and useless device.

In the '90s, as a personal investigation, I designed and built a "Sort-Of Analog Computer" that used cross bar and cross point switches to interconnect a collection of analog circuits such as summing amplifiers, 'differencing' amplifiers, log amplifiers, anti-log amplifiers and a number of other analog circuits designed for single-purpose function. The switches served the part of circuit wiring. A digital program configured the analog circuits into any algorithm or multivariable equation to suit. This gave you the ability to input many variable values simultaneously while generating an output in real-time. The only processing 'speed limit' was determined by the slew rates of the amplifier components used ... I used only generic op amps for the project because they cost only pennies per package. Such a simple way to perform complex tasks ... potentially puts parallel digital processing to shame.

My dad used an analog computer in WWII, which was small enough for his unit to carry with them in the field. He was a tech sergeant in the 292 Field Artillery Observation Battalion, which traveled through France and Germany, spotting and calculating the positions of Nazi artillery. They would operate at night, behind enemy lines. The field computer was connected to microphones that they would set out to record the sound of the artillery guns, and they would use surveying transits to spot the flashes. They would record the transit readings into the computer, the computer would calculate the position of the Nazi guns, and they would radio that info back. Then they would gather their gear and get the heck out of there, because the Nazis had patrols searching for them.

My favourite cross-over between the analogue and digital worlds is the old cellular technology CDMA, it blew my mind when we learned about it at uni.

Basically it allows all mobile phones to communicate at once, without interfering with eachother because it uses the interference itself to encode the signal. Each device is assigned a unique digital code, the device then XORs the data to be transmitted with the code and those bits are transmitted through the air, which interferes with other devices communicating on the same channel. To decode the data for a specific transmitting device, the receiving base station multiplies the transmitter's unique code with the raw signal, and out pops the transmitted data. Constructive interference produces a signal with levels above and below 1 and 0, but when multiplied with the transmitter's code, any values over 1 are interpreted as a 1, and any values below 0 are interpreted as a 0.

One of the best illustrations of an analog computer is sorting numbers using pasta. (This solution is well known to the pastafatarians out there.)

Assume we have a list of random numbers we wish to sort:
For each number,
We cut each strand to a length that is representative of the number.

We gather all the strands together and stand them upright on a flat surface.

We pick out each strand from the longest to the shortest, measure the strand, apply whatever scaling factor we used for the length and write down the number.

Et viola! We have our list of sorted numbers.

Credit: Donald Knuth, "The Art of Computer Programming, Fundamental Algorithms"

I'm glad you touched on analog computers because they've always interested me, but unfortunately you didn't even touch on the largest ones for wartime use. Also just to get it out of the way though I'm sure someone else mentioned it, proximity fuses are the huge difference in why planes were easier to shoot down with anti-aircraft artillery. The directors definitely helped - particularly with radar input - since they could figure out target speed and course and figure out where to aim, but performing any sort of evasive maneuvers would be enough to dodge it due to the time of flight to get an artillery shell up to the plane's altitude. Also the Norden (and the other powers' alternatives, Germany's actually being simpler) was very accurate, with solid testing and training showing a circular error probable of just 75 feet in pre-war. The reason the CEP for all belligerent nations in combat was around 2300 feet is because of things like being shot at and only having reliable wind data from a weather balloon perhaps once a day at the airfield you took off at and not at your target location. Having accurate bomb sights still made a massive difference though and shouldn't be understated.

In any case I have to say I'm disappointed you didn't mention gun fire control systems for naval artillery. Particularly for the larger ships, from late 19th Century pre-dreadnoughts to modern battleships, there was space to put in large analog computers. Without analog computers to calculate trajectories and compensate for the pitching motion from waves, effective engagement ranges would have still only been around what they could have managed with cannons. In comparison, while the actual hit percentage of WW2 naval engagements was around 1%, they could often open up at targets over the horizon. Having fire-control radar even allowed for fairly long engagement ranges at night. Some of the major examples are the USS Washington easily managing to shell the Kirishima only some 5.3 km away during the Battle of Guadalcanal and the USS West Virginia during the Battle of Leyte Gulf managing a hit on her opening salvo against Yamashiro at a range of over 20 km.

As a computer engineer, I was always told that every one has always dreamed to build analog computer because of the enormous performance potential over digital computers. However, it's not that engineers are dumb, that's not that simple.

There is the precision and noise problem that you pointed out, digital component can easily erase noise and restore a digital signal which is very interresting to transmit data over the distance. But in that's not the most important point. We are curently already creating quantum compter which require extreme precision, but there isn't any decisive project for analog computers yet.


In fact in the case of computing the true game changer is timing! Most analog components have time based behaviours, they use analog values of physical constants like voltage, intensity, etc. that doesn't change instantly because they tightly binded to physics laws. When you have a few component moving over a few minutes like old computers presented in the video, it's no big deal, but the nightmare start when you try assembling million, billion or even more of them and syncronizing them at the micro-second or nano-second. And th is not a trivial problem.
On the other side, the main advantage of digital gates is that they are syncronized on a clock. There is a regular clock in your computers (today usually around 4 GHz) and all the memory cells that store bits of data in your computer change there state at the same time when this clock tic. The clock period is designed to be long enough to be sure that every electronic component in the whole computer chip had the time it needed to update its electric state and stabilize its value. Some components would probably take less time than that, but in the end we are garanteed that all electronic signals are stable and reliable. Just with that hypothesis all simulation tools and computer designer can make an enormous simplification by just ignoring all time related physical behaviour and instead focus on a much much much simpler finit state automata. If you look at a processor simulation tool used by computer architects you would not see anything related to voltage, intensity, or physic equations, because all of that is neglected and instead we can focus on much simpler binary signals.

In fact I lied a bit, in practice at the level of miniaturization we reached, we still had to deal with noise, interferance, etc. but that's mostly solved globaly by building robust components and adding shielding around chips when needed, an not by solving the exact physical equaltion between every single electronic components.

It's not that no body tried to do analogus computer but, in history, since the transistor was invented, it has always been simpler and more efficient to reduce complexity with digital computing and compensating by an increased clock speed, adding more parallel transitors computation or a more optimized chip architecture, that trying to work out the complexe equations of billions of analogous electronic components.

It's a little bit like an intersection with traffic lights. It's theoritically possible that everyone pass the intersection at almost full speed by precisely computing everyone's speed. But since cars became widely used, we all accepted that its safer to sync everybody using traffic lights in a binary way.

I had a very interesting childhood full of some amazing opportunities and accomplishments. One such detail was that I built an analog computer for a grade school science fair. I believe I was about 10 and the year was around 1972 or 3. My dad designed jet engines for Pratt & Whitney Aircraft and I was always drawn to math, science and music. I went to the town library looking for books of interesting science projects. I found a book of home science projects using simple, inexpensive items. It had a plan for a simple, cigar box, "analog computer." By your definition here I think it was really a simple  digital computer. It used a cigar box, those copper pins you use with punched whole paper to bind pages together, some wires and some small low power incandescent bulbs. You could add single digit numbers by turning the dials on one and then the number to sum on the other. It showed the result by lighting the appropriate bulb. I blindly accepted the name "analog computer" because it used no transistors or ICs. But unlike the analog computers you showed, there were discrete digits. I think it was a primitive digital computer which is even more impressive for someone in 5th grade. The school system made note of my STEM aptitude. About 3 year later, I was selected as one of 6 kids to go use a PDP11 that had been donated to the school. The other kids were all high schoolers. I was bussed over from the middle school where we were through 9th grade. There was no terminal or printer. Just the PDP11 unit with the dip switches and lights on the front. The other kids goofed off and called it a free day. I taught myself the machine language and figured out how to input two numbers, and yet again, add them. The teachers later told me no one had figured out how to use the thing and asked me how I did it. I said "I studied the thing, read the little manual, and taught myself binary on the spot. They had no idea what I was talking about. Both of these things were extraordinary opportunities. I hope someone reads this and realizes the power of curiosity and critical thinking skills. This was a public school in South Windsor CT and not some fancy private school. Opportunities surround us everyday. All we need to do is seize them. STEM FTW.

In the early 1970's I worked on a helicopter flight simulator that was totally analog. The full size cockpit had fully functional instruments, switches and controls of the real helicopter but the windows were frosted so it was like you were always flying through a dense fog or cloud. Though there were no visual clues the cockpit was hydraulically moved to simulate the G forces you would experience in flight. And it even had a sound system to create the whine of the turbines and whop-whop of the rotor blades.

All the mathematical calculations, including summation, multiplication, integration and differentiation, were performed by transistorized operational amplifiers, servo motors and feedback potentiometers wired together and housed in a 40' semi trailer. There was only one integrated circuit in the whole system and that was an audio amplifier for the sound system.

I still find it amazing that with just a few basic components it was possible at the time to simulate the complex flight of a helicopter in real time.

Mechanical computers and components are useful for NASA missions to planets (ie Venus) were extreme conditions rule out the use of silicon chips and boards. IBM has invented a new system that will continue Mores Law for the foreseeable future.

I'll just drop in a reminder here that digital computers aren't in fact "exact" when it comes to non-integer numerical calculations; unless one is using a special arbitrary-precision math package, there's some loss of accuracy as less-significant bits fall off the bottom of the finite-sized representation of numbers. Order of evaluation can make a big difference where in a mathematically perfect world it wouldn't.
Doing highly iterative calculations without taking the finite precision of the intermediate values into account will yield highly wonky (but consistent!) final results.
(Yes, it's still better than trying to do the same thing with gears. Usually better than analog electronics, with their voltage offsets and temperature coefficients. But it's something that needs to be taken into account.)

2:30 -- saying something is nearly the size of its component parts? This is like saying my keyboard is so small it's nearly the size of a single key! Or, making the kessel run in 12 parsecs. Beyond that, my understanding is transistors aren't 'nearly' the size of atoms, and never will be. We run into quantum tunneling around 1-3 nanometers. So just the barrier portion of a transistor will always need to be around 30 atoms thick, at minimum. Really the main problem we have now is that silicon creates tons of heat as a byproduct, limiting clock speed. If we can find a better medium, we could possibly go into the terahertz range instead of being eternally locked in at around 4-5ghz.

In 1977 I started a position as a control system engineer at the Foxboro company, in Foxboro MA in a group called analog system design. We built analog control systems that ran on air or voltage to control industrial processes. Even with air pressure we could add, subtract, multiply, divide, integrate, differentiate, keep time, store data and build complex algorithms without any electricity involved. Electronic analog computers using operational amplifiers could do this faster and more accurately. The first digital control computers Foxboro built we designed in house, we wrote the real time operating systems, and wrote the applications. They were so slow we worried about control loop response times. We programmed in assembly and machine language to make these expensive machines as fast as possible, and the software was written as function blocks that mimicked analog computer functions like PID controllers to regulate say temperature or pressure. Watching how digital software and hardware evolved over the years was fascinating but many measurement are made with analog sensors so the analog world is still alive.

There's a great story by Arthur Clarke called "The Last Question", written in a time before digital computing existed, and assumed that analog computers would continue to be the way the technology would progress. In the context of this video and the resurgence of analog computing, it's an interesting read.

A key difference between analog and digital computers is how their "software" is written, modified and copied. If you make an analog computer, you are pretty much hard coding the software into the hardware. If you want to make a duplicate of the software, you have to duplicate the hardware. On a digital computer, software is just information encoded into a pattern of 1's and 0's. All you need to do is transfer that information from one computer to another, and as long as the processors are capable of interpreting the information as instruction code, they can process the same exact calculations to generate the same output.
I think analog computers are a red herring distracting us from better computing solutions. If you have a huge bulk of computation that needs to be done, performance gains can be gained by scaling parallel processing and reducing the amount of compute required by choosing better data structures and algorithms.

In [this] UNIVERSE "things" behave in an essentially ANALOG fashion. Digital is, effectively (very effective), a modeling tool. Its version of "things" is essentially mono-linear... like a processing chip or a processing platform. Adding a third dimension to a digital platform will not solve, by processing "depth", the CONUNDRUM (the word ALIASED comes to mind) of applicability in the multi-dimensioned, analog processes present in the "REAL" World. It will remain a digital model, "working" but an approximation.
A CAD-cut flying scale model of a WWII Spitfire, exact in every detail, might look like and function like the REAL thing, but it won't "fly" for the task of accomplishing its designated purpose: Carrying a Human pilot into a heads-on "Boxing" match with a Messerschmidt BF 190. As real as it gets: Proximity and Scale.

CUTTING TO THE CHASE: Back in the Dark Ages of Computers (1975), I used an integrated Analog "harmonic" process/function which was superimposed on a digital processing platform, to truly synthesize a GONG. The goal was not a "synthetic" or "virtual" approximation of a GONG, but to "create" the actual instrument. Still not the REAL thing, but the resultant was CLOSE ENOUGH to "fool" an oscilloscope.

To this day opamps are the bread and butter of electrical engineers, any time a sensor is used on a circuit board (voltage, current, reesistance, temperature, pressure, light, pH,etc.) the signal output will likely require some postprocessing before it can be read by an Analogue-to-Digital Converter (e.g. your ADC might expect a 0 to 5V value, but your sensor produces 0 to 10V values). Once converted, the sensor output can be further manipulated by a digital microcontroller if necessary.
Summing, subtracting, integrating or differentiating signals are easy and can be done with a single opamp, though multiplication and division are slightly more difficult. Luckily you don't need to multiply signals that often when dealing with sensors (and if you do, you can always do it on the digital side where it's easier). You might think it's odd that integrating and differentiating are easier than multiplication, but this comes from the fact that your opamp circuit can include capacitors and inductors, whose behaviours are dictated by equations involving derivatives and integrals. There's a very real sense in which you are offloading the hard part to physics and getting the result for 'free'.

In 1962 I was trained in the U.S. Navy to work with the very first digital computers to be installed on their ships. These were solid state, and state of the art machines. They were intended for control of air and anti-air warfare and the ship I was on had anti-aircraft missiles that took input from the digital computers I worked with, inputs informed by search radars dsplayed on digital display consoles in the Combat Information Center of the ship.
Identified enemy aircraft locations were then handed off to the fire control computers for the missile battery. Those at that time were still analog. I once asked a Fire Control technician about why they did not have digital computers for that purpose, as he was busy with the never ending calibration alignments it needed for its accuracy. On Navy ships every little thing changed with temperature and vibration all the time. He laughed, and told me it wouldn't work fast enough. He was right for that time.

You mentioned that a benefit of digital computers is that they are "exact" however this statement isn't wholly accurate. Digital computers are exposed to quantisation error, when mapping continuous analog values to a discrete number system. While the upside is reproducible answers, the downside is inexactness. While in reality, we can circumvent this problem by using increased precision we can't say that the answers produced are "exact".

One cool thing about the human brain, is that it's both analogue and digital. Each neuron has a resting potential, usually given as -70mV, but depending on the signals it recieves it can be anywhere from around -90mV to just under the threshold potential of -50mV. And the firing of an action potential can either happen, or not happen. So it converts analogue signals (membrane potential) to digital signals (either an action potential being sent, or not). Maybe that's the true future of computers will combine analogue and digital computing into something akin to an animal brain.

The whole comparison between analog and digital computing is a little skewed. The reason we moved to digital computing is that you always get exactly the same answer every time, and you can trivially reconfigure the way it computes those answers without changing anything physical, whether that's by changing the code executed or by reconfiguring a FPGA. You can't really do that with an analog computer, and furthermore you have imprecise answers that accumulate errors through each stage of processing since there's no way to quantitize exactly the data from each step.
Analog computing is very cool but it's never capable of giving exactly the same output over time, affected by temperature, induced electrical noise, component aging, the fundamental noise floor present in any circuit. Try talking to a test engineer about these issues, and how we must have regular calibration of test equipment to maintain standards of accuracy. That just isn't an issue with digital circuitry because we're not measuring exact voltages, but the threshold between two different voltage ranges.

Interesting skip over the contribution to digital computing by the folk at Bletchley Park. Because immediate post war British paranoia was far superior to American post war paranoia, all the work at Bletchley Park was ordered to be destroyed so that it didn’t fall into the wrong hands. It had, however been sequestered by ‘shady folk’ and moved to another location (oh, and also shared with the shady folk over the pond) where the work continued in even greater secrecy and thus the contribution to digital computing of Alan Turing and Tommy Flowers (to name but two of those that contributed at BP) remained unknown until into the 90s. In the meantime, the USA being slightly more commercially minded than their British cousins allowed some of this knowledge into the commercial sector where IBM became. Consequently, popular history records that ENIAC was the first digital programmable computer and the Americans invented it all.

I don't think it's correct the blame the inconsistency of the analog bombing computer for the choice to firebomb Japan. There were a number of successful precision bombing campaigns in Europe during WWII. The barrier to precision bombing in Japan was the jet stream

In order to avoid counterattacks by Japanese planes, the allied B-29s approach at higher elevations than previous bombing campaigns - 30,000 feet. At this height, pilots reported strong winds unlike any encountered before. These winds made it impossible to drop bombs accurately enough to hit precision targets. This was actually how the jet stream was discovered, the winds were reported back to central command, and they eventually spoke with meteorologists who realized they had uncovered a new phenomenon

The original plan of precision bombing was scrapped and replaced with the horrific firebombing campaign described in the video

Quick side note: digital does not necessarily mean binary, and from a hardware point of view, it often doesn't. An example of that would be modern QLC NAND flash, where each cell can be charged to any of sixteen different voltage levels, which means four bits can be stored in each cell. Very soon newer variants of high speed interfaces like PCI express (PCIe 6.0) will also migrate from switching the signal between two different voltages (i.e. on or off; that's what binary is) to four and in the future probably even more than that, so they can increase the speed without having to run it at higher and higher frequencies. On the inside of digital chips, liberal use is made of tri-state logic, whereby the output of a logic element can either be a one, a zero, or left floating, to be overridden by another logic element on the same line. This is much more efficient than trying to solve the same problem with an array of OR gates like you might think this is done.
And yet boolean logic is so hard  to understand, near impossible when using eurorack  synthesis.

You state digital computers are exact, repeatable and robust to noise. In theory you are right, if you neglect all real circumstances in the assumptions. But in practice you are wrong. They are for 99.99999% of the time, but not 100% of the time. That is why we have ECC-RAM in Servers. That is why not all cpus of the same batch run at same frequencies, because they would fail. Et cetera, et cetera, et cetera. We always push the limits further, but there are limits where the digital computers at a time are not exact, not repeatable nor robust to noise. It's not God-given, it's the hard work of engineers.

There are a couple of unstated things that have led Analog Computers to have taken a great backseat to Digital Ones. I also will make a comment about where I think your next video is headed.

I think everyone knows that Digital Computers have gone through an insane cost reduction and power growth curve at the same time. This doesn't just include processing power but power, memory and storage as well. Analog Computers have not been anywhere near as scalable to date. In a massive oversimplification, the noise problem that is mentioned carries over into analog devices in many ways. This means that analog electronics just has not been able to go through that same revolution cost, processing, and storage revolution.

The second problem is exhibited throughout the presentation. That is that Analog Computers, as we know them today, solve one problem at a time. We have yet to come up with an effective way of creating the equivalent of software to drive the development of analog computers. Imagine having a different computers to run YouTube, Netflix, Gmail, etc. You can make make analog computers out of general purpose components, but you would have to reconfigure them to run different applications. I am old enough to have to have "programmed" analog computers to solve circuit problems in Engineering school. The computations to set them up correctly to make good waveforms often took hours or days.

So, I suspect where Derek is heading is a new burst of neural network research. These have been around a long time and are intended to emulate the working of the human brain, which would theoretically lead to a general purpose Analog Computer. Will be interesting to see if anything meaningful has been done in the last 30+ years (which is the last time I paid attention to this). We could make 10ish neurons at that time and had found some ways to solve specific problems with learning. Scalability and general purpose were not solved problems.

I do want to point out on the rather incredibly improvement of shells/kill ratios of Allied AA guns: that wasn't solely down to better maneuvering of the guns. Planes are fast and small, so hitting them in three dimensional space is really difficult. The Americans and the British jointly developed the proximity fuse, basically a way for the shell to detect when it was near an enemy plane and detonate, and this at least removed the third dimension from their aim, making them much more accurate.

Hypothesis: Using digital computers to manufacture analogue computers will dramatically decrease the failure rate of the analogue computer due to the precision and consistency of the digital computer.

How to test: Design an analogue computer who's purpose is to measure the fluctuation of something commonly understood. Build one version of this computer the traditional way, and the other version, using the digital computer. The constant being the fluctuation being recorded (a pattern or system already well understood, something we don't NEED to measure anymore), and the only variables being the way the analogue computers are manufactured.

The conclusion of the experiment should give us an idea of how digital and analogue combined can effect the consistency (or remove the inconsistency) of analogue technology.

I hate to be the pedant, but the Norden bombsight wasn't a failure because it was analog.  It continued to serve with distinction in the Atlantic theater.  It's failure came from being installed in the much higher flying B-29's in the Pacific theater.  When it encountered the jet stream over Japan for the first time, it had to compute groundspeeds that to that time were undreamt of.  This is an example of input saturation, not an inherent weakness in analog systems (poorly designed/imagined digital systems are exposed to this failure too).

Fun fact: lenses can also compute. When you illuminate a film with collimated light and place a lens with a screen in its focal plane behind it, it will project a Fraunhofer diffraction pattern, which is a Fourier transform. Optical systems like this can compute two-dimensional Fourier transforms at the speed of light. They were used in the 70s at universities because they were MUCH faster at transforms than digital computers.

Both of them are digital computers. When you use gears, you are quantizing rotation in discrete fractions of a turn. Like digital computers, you are "stuck" with using rational numbers in the calculations. (A computer with gears COULD NOT calculate the length of the square's diagonal, given its side.) That other mechanism could be analog if you move the lever partway between 0 and 1. The gear computer is approximating analog ratios by the nearest ratio of whole numbers. Run that eclipse calculator long enough, & its answers will drift off from correct predictions because of this approximation.
There are still lots of "analog" computers. Every piece of "digital" audio equipment has an analog section between the mic & the digital computer's input, & between the digital computer's output & the speaker. The demands placed upon these analog sections is greater than ever with the increased precision demanded. "Switching" power supplies also have analog control sections to regulate them. The power supplies for the digital computers are analog.

There were two kinds of analog computers: mechanical and electronic. Electronic analog computers were developed during WWII, where they were used to control radar-directed gunfire, by making ballistic calculations. George Philbrick was involved in the development of these computers and went on to form a private firm that produced the components used in analog computers and also constructed large scale analog computers that were very important during the 1950s and 1960s.......Some firms involved were George A Philbrick Researches, Burr-Brown,  Fairchild Semiconductor, and National Semiconductor, all of whom applied analog computation techniques to many other electronic fields.

One of the big problems with neural networks is that they're often just a black box that we give input and it spits out answers, it's good if you just want answers, but what if you wanted to know how it's figuring it out? Traditionally, you're out of luck. However, since analogue computers are physical representations of the computation it performs, if you could train an neural network to design an analogue computer that solves the problem, we could extrapolate what calculations the neural net is actually performing, and possibly gain some insight into the problem we're trying to solve.

Sounds promising to me.

When I began as an undergrad 50 years ago, after experiencing numerical analysis with mechanical calculators, then on an Elliot 903, we moved on to analogue computers. As a Physicist I wondered why anybody would want to programme a digital computer to solve differential equations when it took a couple of minutes to patch the equation into the analogue box, and results came out instantly as the variables were changed - rather than punching a new paper tape, queueing to feed it in, then after dealing with error messages trying again and getting the result.

I spent two 'gap' years working on British Government work (the Official Secrets Act prevents me speaking further), and when I returned to university the analogue devices had been scrapped.

I have a permanent eBay watch for an EAI TR20 - the device on which I lost my analogue virginity.

Where do you build a factory?
Analog computer for the win!

Build a scale-model of the area under consideration, say a few meters on a side.
Drill holes in the model where raw materials, energy, labor and all other commodities come from.
Drop a string down through each hole, and attach a weight. The weights are proportional to the real-world cost of moving that commodity.
On top of the model, all the strings are tied together on a brass ring.
The ring will be dragged by the weights and the deflected by the angles of the strings to a point on the model where the cost are 'normalized'.
The cost of getting any one item to the factory is well balanced against all others.
